prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 continuum of H-[4.5]>4 galaxies in UDS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This Science Goal aims at detecting the sub-mm continuum of 8 galaxies with H-[4.5]>4 in the UDS/CANDELS field, in the ALMA Band 7.
The chosen correlator setup is within the lowest-frequency half of Band 7 to ensure maximum atmospheric transmission within that band.
In spite that the main aim of this proposal is continuum detection, we have chosen to do observations in a high-resolution spectral mode with bandwidth=1875 MHz and resolution=3.9 MHz, in order to resolve the [CII] line that may fall within the Band 7 for two sources with estimated redshifts z~4.92-4.94. The spectral windows have been chosen accordingly.
The integration times have been computed using 'AggregateBandWidth' with the desired continuum sensitivities, i.e. the integration times have been optimnised for continuum detection, which is the main aim of this proposal.
All source redshifts have been set to 0 simply to make the AOT use the same sky frequency window for all the targets. Line peak flux has been set to continuum flux, unless a [CII] detection is expected (the ALMA OT requires setting line peak flux for all targets if spectral line setup is chosen).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to detect the continuum of our targets close to the peak of the IR emission at rest ~100-200 microns. The ALMA Band 7 is the most suitable because:
* our sources lie at z>3, so the negative k-corrections favour observations at ~400-1000 microns.
* Band 7 has higher sensitivity than Bands 8 or 9, and is less sensitive to weather conditions.
* Although Band 6 has a factor of ~1.7 better continuum sensitivity than Band 7, this fact is compensated by our targets being brighter by a similar factor in Band 7 than in Band 6. For this proposal, Band 7 has the advantage that it could yield the detection of [CII] for two of our targets (while any serendipitous line detection in Band 6 is unlikely). And, although Band 6 is less sensitive to weather conditions than Band 7, the total time requested by this proposal is so small that it could easily be accommodated within the Band 7 observing time (note that our sources are distributed over two fields with very different RA, providing more flexibility for the scheduling).
The predicted Band 7 flux densities of all our targets are Snu(0.9 mm) > 1.0 mJy. According to the ALMA time calculator, we can achieve Snu(0.9 mm)=1.0 mJy (10 sigma) with only ~5 min on-source. This is a very small time investment for such a high-impact science case.
The ALMA compact configuration C32-1 is the most suitable for our targets, as we only aim for source detection rather than mapping. We will obtain an angular resolution in Band 7 of 1.2 arcsec, which is comparable to the resolution in the IRAC bands (1.9 arcsec). A S/N=10 will allow us to achieve an astrometric accuracy dtheta < 0.1 arcsec, assuming dtheta ~ 0.6x FWHM / (S/N), which is perfect to match the ALMA and IRAC sources. The primary beam FOV is ~20 arcsec, which is more than enough to contain our targets (typical size~3-4 arcsec).
Our four basebands have been chosen within the lowest-frequency half of Band 7, for maximum atmospheric transmission. In particular, the basebands avoid the 325GHz water line.
We will use a FDM-mode correlator setup with dual polarization and four bandwidths of 1875 MHz with resolution=3.9MHz, in case that the [CII] line falls within the observed spectral window. This is equivalent to a resolution < 4km/s, which is sufficient to resolve the [CII] line with estimated v_obs~30km/s, and at the same time guarantees that the data rate keeps below the average value. We will then integrate over the entire 7.5 GHz range to achieve the desired continuum sensitivities (the integration times are based on these sensitivities, as continuum detection is the main focus of this proposal).
To minimize overheads, all targets have been grouped in two science goals with the same observational setup (one science goal per field).
Note that overheads only make ~20% of the requested observing time of this proposal (there is 45% of time on source and 35% of time on calibrators).

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 7 continuum of H-[4.5]>4 galaxies in COSMOS
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
This Science Goal aims at detecting the sub-mm continuum of 10 galaxies with H-[4.5]>4 in the COSMOS field, in the ALMA Band 7.
The chosen correlator setup is within the lowest-frequency half of Band 7 to ensure maximum atmospheric transmission within that band.
In spite that the main aim of this proposal is continuum detection, we have chosen to do observations in a high-resolution spectral mode with bandwidth=1875 MHz and resolution=3.9 MHz, in order to resolve any serendipitously-detected line that may fall within the Band 7. The spectral windows are the same as for Science Goal 1.
The integration times have been computed using 'AggregateBandWidth' with the desired continuum sensitivities, i.e. the integration times have been optimised for continuum detection, which is the main aim of this proposal.
All source redshifts have been set to 0 simply to make the AOT use the same sky frequency window for all the targets. Line peak flux has been set to continuum flux for each target (the ALMA OT requires setting line peak flux for all targets if spectral line setup is chosen).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We aim to detect the continuum of our targets close to the peak of the IR emission at rest ~100-200 microns. The ALMA Band 7 is the most suitable because:
* our sources lie at z>3, so the negative k-corrections favour observations at ~400-1000 microns.
* Band 7 has higher sensitivity than Bands 8 or 9, and is less sensitive to weather conditions.
* Although Band 6 has a factor of ~1.7 better continuum sensitivity than Band 7, this fact is compensated by our targets being brighter by a similar factor in Band 7 than in Band 6. And, although Band 6 is less sensitive to weather conditions than Band 7, the total time requested by this proposal is so small that it could easily be accommodated within the Band 7 observing time (note that our sources are distributed over two fields with very different RA, providing more flexibility for the scheduling).
The predicted Band 7 flux densities of all our targets are Snu(0.9 mm) > 1.0 mJy. According to the ALMA time calculator, we can achieve Snu(0.9 mm)=1.0 mJy (10 sigma) with only ~5 min on-source. This is a very small time investment for such a high-impact science case.
The ALMA compact configuration C32-1 is the most suitable for our targets, as we only aim for source detection rather than mapping. We will obtain an angular resolution in Band 7 of 1.2 arcsec, which is comparable to the resolution in the IRAC bands (1.9 arcsec). A S/N=10 will allow us to achieve an astrometric accuracy dtheta < 0.1 arcsec, assuming dtheta ~ 0.6x FWHM / (S/N), which is perfect to match the ALMA and IRAC sources. The primary beam FOV is ~20 arcsec, which is more than enough to contain our targets (typical size~3-4 arcsec).
Our four basebands have been chosen within the lowest-frequency half of Band 7, for maximum atmospheric transmission. In particular, the basebands avoid the 325GHz water line.
As in the other science goal, we will use a FDM-mode correlator setup with dual polarization and four bandwidths of 1875 MHz with resolution=3.9MHz. This is equivalent to a resolution < 4km/s, which is sufficient for resolving any possible serendipitously-detected line, and at the same time guarantees that the data rate is below the average value. We will then integrate over the entire 7.5 GHz range to achieve the desired continuum sensitivities (the integration times are based on these sensitivities, as continuum detection is the main focus of this proposal).
To minimize overheads, all targets have been grouped in two science goals with the same observational setup (one science goal per field).
Note that overheads only make ~20% of the requested observing time of this proposal (there is 45% time on source and 35% of time on calibrators).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We request 3.0 hours in ALMA Band 7 to detect the dust continuum emission of 18 bright Spitzer/IRAC galaxies at z>3 that are very faint at 1.6 microns, with colours H-[4.5]>4. The ALMA detections will prove that our targets are powerful dusty starbursts, similar in nature to the rare sub-millimetre source GN10 at z=4. Our main goals are: 1) detect the Band 7 continuum of our targets to increase by a factor of eight the number of known GN10-like sources, and show that this rare class of z>3 sub-millimetre sources is actually much more common than previously thought; 2) estimate the obscured star formation rates (SFR) of our z>3 targets, and derive their contribution to the total SFR density at high z; 3) analyse the 24 micron/Band 7 flux excess to weigh the contribution of an AGN component to the overall dust emission; 4) use the Band 7 detection of two z~6 candidates to exclude that they are low-z contaminants. Our observations in Band 7 could also yield a [CII] detection for two of our targets. This high-impact proposal will demonstrate the power of ALMA to reveal a new population of massive, dusty starbursts at z>3 that are at the detection limit of the deepest near-IR surveys.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: There is another cycle2 proposal (PI Kohno) to do imaging over 36 arcmin^2 of the UDS field with the ALMA Band 6. Only two of the targets proposed for observations here lie within in this area. If both proposals are accepted, the ALMA Band 6 observations of the other programme will complement our Band 7 observations.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: One of our targets will have ALMA Band 6 observations from a cycle-1 carried-over program (2012.1.00756.S; PI Kohno).
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Kapteyn Astronomical Institute, University of Groningen
